data.text: @DocMCohen Maybe there's value in keeping FP's free from having to do the assembly-line mass vax work and leverage their existing patient relationships to solve the last mile problem on this?
@DocMCohen Doesn't it make sense to use family docs for the hardest to reach folks?  I imagine mass clinics have been way more efficient for the majority if the population.

@BilasHeidi @DocMCohen My vaccination centre six hour shift I vaccinated not a single first dose. At vaccination clinic in my FP clinic I gave three first doses out of a vial of ten. All they needed was counselling of risks and benefits with dash of my personal stories and that I’m there for them
@kristatee @alandrummond2 @DocMCohen Yes - I am also a doctor hunter -.her FP retired- often based on referrals and is a challenge in rural ON #familydoctors

@SandyTecimer @kristatee @DocMCohen 4/ Finally - the cost of setting up mass vaccine sites is far more than using family doctors we have. The cost of sidelining family medicine - and how discouraged they are by this - will cost us family doctors. That’s unforgivable.
@SandyTecimer @kristatee @DocMCohen 3/ We were put at risk and that worried me 👇🏽 https://t.co/TngQmMGZ2A
@SandyTecimer @DocMCohen I agree completely that FP should have been involved sooner + plans to roll out to those without doctors.

@SandyTecimer @kristatee @DocMCohen 2/ If family doctors were included they would have identified vulnerable patients and vaccinated quickly. Those without family doctors could have been easily handled by pharmacies and vaccine sites, instead of the mad rush. Further, sidelining family medicine devalues them.

@SandyTecimer @kristatee @DocMCohen 1/Arguing who doesn’t have a family doctor isn’t useful. Vaccines have been rolled out for everything, including yearly flu shots, by family doctors, pharmacists and clinics. To bypass family doctors took away a significant vaccine arm and sidelined a crucial engine for vaccines.
@BossenberryCath @alandrummond2 @DocMCohen I hope she gets one. But I know it can be hard in many areas!
@HilaryWollis @SandyTecimer @DocMCohen Last stats I read was close to 1/4 (if you include rural areas)
@bernardcampagna @DocMCohen Good point. That wasn’t clear either.

@SandyTecimer @DocMCohen 1/4 of people in Kingston don’t have a family doctor. I’ve seen some communities are as high as 1/3. Some areas have majority family doctors, but there are regions with major % of population without one.
@SandyTecimer @kristatee @DocMCohen In KWC many family doctors are the urgent care clinic physicians. Krista is right -there should have been a plan.
@kristatee @alandrummond2 @DocMCohen My 39yr daughter does not have a FP - I was her vaccine hunter- crazy!

@SandyTecimer @kristatee @DocMCohen There are thousands of people in #ygk Kingston #KFLA who would disagree as they wait years to be matched with a family doctor. And drive 3 hours back to a former community to access care. #Ontario

@SandyTecimer @LeslieMaggie @kristatee @DocMCohen It actually surprised me that family doctors weren't given resources to administer the vaccine themselves. It would've lessened the load on the system as a lot of people would check if their docs had the vaccine available.
@kristatee @DocMCohen Are they actually going to actually let them vaccinate? Sounds like their plan is to have FP cold call their patients only

@kristatee @DocMCohen The majority of Ontarians have a family doctor. 

Resources should’ve been put into supporting family doctors to vaccinate from the start as well as an alternate steam for those who don’t have one.
@DocMCohen FP are exhausted, and now they do this? And what is their plan for the many Ontarians without a primary care provider?
@DocMCohen PERFECTLY SAID!!!
@DocMCohen Exactly. Grr.
